EExecutive Summary

Rancho Murieta Community Services District (RMCSD) has been requested by the cognizant Administrative Agency, Sacramento County Environmental Management Department, Hazardous Materials Department (SCEMD) to prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Water Treatment Plant site which contains a Regulated Substance (RS). This request was made in March 1997 pursuant to California Health and Safety Code division 20, Chapter 6.95, Article 2, Section 25534 (b)(1) and California Code of regulations (CCR) title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP). This RMP is being prepared to identify the equipment, procedures, maintenance, inspection, and training associated with the regulated substance (RS); to record a structured assessment of hazards which may affect offsite public and environmental receptors; to provide the results of an offsite consequences analysis; to define a prevention program, emergency response program, and mitigation measures to reduce the probability and magnitude of accidental releases of RS's; and to establish a schedule and responsibilities for implementation of mitigation measures and auditing of program elements. This submission is to recertify the program at the Federal level by a 5-year update.  This program was previously certified in the State of California as part of the CalARP program in 2015.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is the policy of RMCSD that the receipt, storage and handling of chlorine at its facilities be done in a manner which meets regulatory requirements and minimizes the probability and severity of releases of chlorine to the atmosphere, in order to protect the health and safety of its workers, the public and the environment. In order to accomplish this goal, RMCSD has gathered safety information on chlorine and on the process, equipment and procedures involving chlorine; performed an offsite consequences analysis of def

ined release scenarios; established a written program for prevention and mitigation of releases; and established a written emergency response program coordinated with emergency response agencies.  

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

RMCSD produces, treats and distributes domestic water and provides wastewater collection and reclamation services.  Its administrative offices are located at 15160 Jackson Highway, Rancho Murieta, in Sacramento County. It operates a water treatment plant and a wastewater reclamation facility among other facilities.  The RS used at the RMCSD facilities and considered in this RMP is chlorine.  The water treatment plant uses surface water to supply the local community.  The water is treated at the plant and disinfected with chlorine gas.


General Accidental Release Prevention Programs

General accidental release prevention programs instituted by RMCSD are categorized as administrative (management) programs; procedures, training, engineering controls and PPE; as well as emergency response programs. 

Chemical Specific Release Prevention Steps

Release prevention steps specific to chlorine have been identified and implemented. These include, among other things, installation of chlorine leak detectors and alarm telemetry at the sites, creating facility specific procedures for cylinder receiving, transport, hookup, and leak response; and installing seismic restraint systems for the ton containers. Automatic shutoff valves have been installed to limit the quantity released in the event of a release.

Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidents involving chorine at RMCSD facilities in Sacramento County within the past five years which resulted in injuries or offsite effects. 

Emergency Response Program

RMCSD's Emergency Response Program applicable to chlorine consists of First Response actions related to chlorine release emergencies, notification of neighbors and notification of local emergen

cy responders covering the geographical area where the release occurs.  In addition, state agencies are notified for releases and federal agencies are notified for releases in excess of the Reportable Quantity for chlorine.  RMCSD has coordinated its emergency response program with the local agencies.  RMCSD's sites are also included in the Sacramento County area plan.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

All of the improvements and mitigation measures identified in the process hazardous analysis which RMCSD has committed to accomplish have been completed or are in progress. Any other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys, or as a result of audit activities, will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.  RMCSD is committed to inherently safer technology.  It is in the process of moving from chlorine gas to sodium hypochlorite.
